title: Gastón Arce Sejas
description: Composer, conductor, and researcher Acre studied musical composition with Mariano Etkin and Gabriel Valverde and orchestral conducting with Guillermo Scarabino and Mario Benzecry at the Department of the Arts at La Plata University (UNLP) in Buenos Aires, Argentina. In 2000, Acre founded the bachelor's degree in music at Loyola University of Bolivia in La Paz, where he served as the music department head and instructor. While at Loyola University, Acre spearheaded the development of a bachelor's of music degree in traditional orchestral instruments; established the Ensemble PRETA, which combines traditional Bolivian musical instruments with digital technologies; and the Loyola Sinfonietta. In addition, Acre has established various musical ensembles such as the Ensemble Contemporáneo TAKY, which exclusively plays contemporary Bolivian and Latin American classical music, and co-founded the Curucusí Ensemble with soprano Giovanna Montaño.                                                                                                                                                       During his extensive career, Acre has taught at the Major University of San Andrés, the El Alto Public University, and the Tomás Frías de Potosí University. Between 2012 and 2016, he was the Municipal de El Alto Symphony Orchestra at the Municipal School of Arts (EMDA) director. His more than 70 compositions are performed frequently inside and outside of Bolivia. In October 2016, he received the "Orlando Alandia Pantoja National Composition Award." In 2017, the Venezuelan Symphony Orchestra premiered Gritos de Cóndor (Cries of a Condor), an honorable mention from the same contest from 2012. In 2017, Acre released his sell-out hit Los Avatares de la Música Contemporánea en Bolivia (The Avatars of Contemporary Music in Bolivia), which examines the history of contemporary Bolivian music in the last decade and its leading figures. The book's success has prompted Acre to begin writing a second edition.

title: Fernando Arduz
description:
Born in Tarija Arduz began in studying music with his hometown legend, maestro Ernesto La Faye “Don Ernesto”  in1973. He attended four international guitar seminars with Uruguayan maestro Abel Carlevaro in Montevideo, Uruguay. Arduz obtained the title of Superior Professor of Guitar at the Royal Superior Conservatory of Music in Madrid, Spain. He directed the Tarija Chamber Orchestra since its creation and taught at The Municipal School of Regional Music “Pastor Achá Martínez,” He has held concerts in Bolivia, Spain and Argentina. His compositions and arrangements have been premiered and performed in Spain (Alfar duo), Germany (Trío Arabesque), Japan (Gentaro Takada), Spain (Gabriel Estarellas), Argentina (Camerata Lyrum) and Bolivia (National Symphony Orchestra, Tajira Chamber Orchestra  Tarija", Departmental Symphony Orchestra of Tarija), and various Bolivian and foreign guitarists.
        His body of work include musical compositions and books. The books he published throughout his lifetime include the Bolivian Music for Guitar (1993); Alfredo Domínguez, Works for Guitar (2002), and Small Works and Studies for Guitar (2004). He co-edited the book Music and Traditional Songs of Tarija with Dr. Lorenzo Calzavarini (1999). Arduz  has also collaborated with his daughter Adriana, to make the interactive CD Enciclopedia de Música Chapaca (Encyclopedia of Chapaca Music) (2008), and with the Tarija Chamber Orchestra to record tthe CD Tarija y la Música de él (Tarija and his music) (2009). In 2013, he released the CD Paisajes: Fernando Arduz (Landscapes: Fernando Arduz). Arduz has also has received recognitions for his work including the “Premio Plurinacional Eduardo Abaroa” from the Ministry of Culture and Tourism of the Plurinational State of Bolivia in the category of Folk music arrangement for symphony orchestra for his work Vida, pasión y muerte de Juan Cutipa” de Alfredo Domínguez (Life, passion and death of Juan Cutipa by Alfredo Domínguez) in 2014. The Ministry of Education awarded him the title of Master of Arts in Music in 2015. He passed away in Tarija in December 2021.

title: Christian Orlando Asturizaga
description:
Principal conductor of the Chuquiago Marka Symphony Orchestra and concertmaster of the Bolivian National Symphony Orchestra, an institution he was director of from 2015 to 2017. His artistic experience led him to perform on the main national stages and he began his international career at an early age representing Bolivia. He participated in several orchestral projects of international convocation such as a World Orchestra in Interlochen. Asturizaga has also participated in national projects such as the Youth Orchestra of the Andean Countries, and 
la Orquesta de la Unión de Naciones Suramericanas (UNASUR), which allowed him to participate in concerts in Switzerland, the United States, China, France, tours of South America, Europe and Bolivia.
      As a teacher, researcher, and graduate project advisor, Asturizaga has contributed to the training of new generations at the National Conservatory of Music in La Paz (CNM), the Luis Felipe Arce Artistic Training Institute, the Universidad Mayor de San Andrés, and the Bolivian Private University. He has also been invited to give talks in Peru, the U.S., and France. In 2007 he received recognition for his pedagogical work and contribution to Bolivian musical culture. 
      Asturizaga studied at the CNM (Bolivia), Morges Conservatory (Switzerland), and the Metz Regional Conservatory (France) with violinist Denis Clavier. He received a scholarship to the Interlochen Arts Camp (USA), which changed his interest in music and lead him to study him to enhance his artistic profile. He studied conducting, composition, and arrangements at Loyola University of Bolivia in La Paz, received a master's degree in orchestral conducting from the University Public School of El Alto and at the Francisco Navarro Lara orchestra and band Conducting School.
    For his contribution to Bolivian culture, he has been distinguished with the "Honor of Cultural Merit" medal, recognition and tribute as a "Meritorious Personality of the Plurinational State of Bolivia,” the "Chukuta de Oro" and others from the Legislative Assembly. In 2022, he was recognized for his remarkable career among 10 other representative national artists by the Club of La Paz.

title: Atiliano Auza León
description: Born in the historic city of Sucre, Bolivia, composer, violinist, and musicologist Auza Leon began his musical studies at the Academy of Music of the Philharmonic Society of Sucre at 18 in 1946. He transferred a year later (1947) to the Higher Teacher Training School of Sucre (1947-1951). In 1953, Auza Leon studied composition at the National Conservatory of Music in La Paz with exiled Jewish German maestro Eric Eisner, the founder and first director of the National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia. In 1965, he studied at the Latin American Center for Higher Musical Studies (CLAEM), a program developed in partnership with the Torcuato Di Tella Institute and the Rockefeller Foundation in Buenos Aires, Argentina, under the direction of the Argentine composer Alberto Ginastera. Upon his return to Bolivia in the 1970s, Auza Leon taught at various institutions, including the Simón Bolívar Higher Teacher Training School of Music in La Paz, where he directed the choir, and at the National Conservatory of Music of La Paz, where he taught composition.                                                                                                                                                            Throughout his lifetime Auza Leon has written numerous compositions for violin, choir, and orchestra, including "Ramillete Sonoro" (1958) in three volumes, a collection of Bolivian songs for children; "Sies danzas Bolivianas del Ciclo 'Runas'" (Six Bolivian dances of the "Runas" cycle) (1960) which features popular songs "El panuelo" and "A la cueca"; the piano sonatas "Anfiblástula" (1965) and "Los Chunchos" (1979); and "La Cantata Oda a Moto Méndez" (1984) an ode to Bolivian freedom fighter Eustaquio "Moto" Méndez. Most notably, he wrote the music for the first Bolivian Opera, "Incallajta" (1980), which narrates the impossible love story between an Incan princess and a warrior. His latest compositions, "Melodías Nacionales para Piano" (National Melodies for Piano)(1999); "Danzas Bolivianas para Violín y Piano" (Ciclo Runas 2°) (Bolivian Dances for Violin and Piano (Runas 2° Cycle)) (2000); and "Sinfonía Boliviana" (Bolivian Symphony)(2006) in four movements demonstrate his dedication to Bolivian music. In addition to his musical work, Auza Leon has written several Bolivian music history books and published articles in the National Press. His most important works include Dinámica Musical en Bolivia (Musical Dynamics in Bolivia) (1967), Musica Contemporanea (Contemporary Music) (1976), and Historia de la Música Boliviana (History of Bolivian Music) (1985), which three sold-out editions.

title: Martha Patricia Bedregal Velasco
description: When Velasco was four years old, she started taking piano lessons, and when she was nine, she began to study music at the National Conservatory of Bolivia. In 1990, at 18, Velasco decided to pursue a degree in architecture and, after graduation, worked in this field. Eight years later, in 1998, she returned to her music studies with her mentors, Maestro Javier Parrado and Maestra Mariana Alandia. In 2006, she began to pursue a bachelor’s degree in composition at the Loyola University of Bolivia in La Paz with Gastón Arce. Her return to music led Velasco to perform with the National Symphony Orchestra, Bolivian Choral Society, and the Philarmonic de La Paz from 2001 to 2017. She also participated in projects such as the “Trio ‘Abismos’” a horn, piano, and cello ensemble as a pianist and composer, and the fusion project “Mústika.” Between 1990 and 2013, Velasco taught at the National Music Conservatory in La Paz, where she was appointed academic director.                                                                                           Velasco's composition premiered at the Contemporary Music Journey in Cochabamba in 2006. In 2014, “Stockholm Saxophone Quartet,” a Swedish saxophone quartet dedicated to playing contemporary music, commissioned a composition from her to add to their repertoire. The song she composed was performed in various concerts in North Europe and Africa. In 2020, the quartet requested a new composition for a children’s choir and saxophone quartet, entitled “Pachamama,” which premiered in April 2021 in Sweden. In addition to being a composer, Velasco is also a prolific music arranger. She arranged the artist and author of Sonia Rolón album “Voy Yo Misma a Desnudarte” (“I'm Going to Undress You Myself”) in 2011. She made orchestral arrangements for the Chilean Andean group Altiplano in 2012. She was the official arranger for the symphonic tribute projects for Pink Floyd (2013), Beatles (2014), and ABBA (2015) with Deuce Producciones.                                                                                                                                      Velasco's trajectory as an arranger led her to work with the Colombian electronic experimental musical group Ambivalencias in 2014, with the Bolivian rock metal group Armadura and the National Symphony Orchestra. She also worked on the translation and arrangements for the Soda Stereo Unplugged along with the group Ruido Blanco in 2015. She arranged pieces for “Sinfomore:” a symphonic homage to Argentian rock music, held by the Youth Symphony Orchestra of the Plurinational Conservatory of Music in Argentina. She also arranged for a string quartet for the Bolivian rock band Ciudad Líquida for the album “Frecuencias Fantasma” in 2016. Velasco also made symphonic arrangements for the “Festijazz,” for maestro Gilberto Rojas's work in 2016, for the “Homenaje a la Mujer” (Homage to Women) in 2017, and arranged for and produced the concert “Sangre y Sueños” (Blood and Dreams) a tribute to Bolivian author and singer Marcelo Urioste. She also made symphonic arrangements for Manuel Monroy Chazarreta’s “Papirri Sinfónico” Concert in 2018 and symphonic arrangements for Adrian Barrenechea´s music for “Un Concierto Muy Sui Generis,” along with Nito Mestre in 2018.                                                                                                                                             In 2020, she made an orchestral arrangement version of the song “De Regreso Agradezco a la Vida” (On the way back, I thank life) based on the cueca “De Regreso” (On the way back) from Bolivian composer Matilde Casazola and “Gracias a la Vida” (Thank to life) from Chilean composer Violeta Parra. These arrangements were performed virtually by the Bolivian Female Orchestra and the Female Orchestra of Chile on October 3rd of the same year. She is currently dedicating her time to teaching and composing.

title: Lluvia Bustos Soria
description: Composer Bustos Soria received a bachelor's degree in music arts from the Bolivian Catholic University, a Master of Arts in musical composition, theory of cinema and film, television and audiovisual media music from Beijing Film Academy (BFA), and a degree in electrical engineering from the Universidad Mayor de San Andrés (UMSA) in La Paz.                                                                                                                              Bustos Soria has worked on commissions for the Orquesta Experimental de Instrumentos Nativos (Experimental Native Instruments Orchestra)(OEIN). This orchestra incorporates the sounds of traditional instruments from the Bolivian Andes to contemporary classical music. She has also worked with the Cultural Center Simon I. Patiño and for the PRO ESCENA Music Festival of the Cultural Center of Spain in La Paz, Bolivia. In Beijing, Bustos Soria worked on the soundtrack of various short films selected to represent the Beijing Youth Studio at international film festivals. In January 2009, she worked on the soundtrack of “Munian De Kunhuo” (complex and baffling old age), produced in partnership with the Beijing Drama Academy and the Institute of Mental Health in Beijing. Bustos Soria also did the audio post-production of the documentary “El Corral Y El Viento” (The Corral And The Wind) (2014) by Miguel Hilari. Her compositions have been played in different countries at contemporary music festivals and sound art festivals.                                                                    In addition to her work as a composer, Bustos Soria also heads different projects with the Museo Nacional de Etnografía y Folklore (National Museum of Ethnography and Folklore) (MUSEF) archive, including cataloging, preserving, and recovery of film material and digitizing and editing of analog cassettes from the Sound Documents Fund. She also heads a project that is working on adding audio descriptions and close captioning to Bolivian films, the project “El Color de la Imaginación” (The Color of Imagination) audio stories for children volumes one and two. She has partnered with Sonido Con Alta Techonlogia (SCAT), an audio and audiovisual production company, to develop the “Mapa sonoro del municipio de La Paz” (Sound map of the municipal of La Paz”) project. Bustos Soria has also produced and organized the First Bolivian Tiflo-cinema Mini-festival, “Francesco Díaz Mariscal,” in 2014.

title: Miguel Cerruto
description:
At the age of 20, Cerruto went to live in the United States and later Spain. When he was 31, he studied at the Superior Conservatory of Music in Seville, Spain, earning a teacher's diploma in classical guitar.
    As a student, he started composing pieces for guitar and other ensembles. He worked at the Conservatorio Plurinacional de Música in La Paz from 1990 to 2000, where he created the Classical Guitar department, along with Kazutoyo Ito and Gentaro Takada

title: Oldrich Halas
description:
Composer, teacher, and graphic artist, Halas was born in La Paz, Bolivia in 1967 to a Potosi mother and a Czech father. His mother is from Potosi, Bolivia and his father is  mother and a Czech father. In 1986 he made his debut as a composer at a concert in La Paz shared with Alberto Villalpando and and Willy Pozadas. That same year, Halas entered the National Conservatory of Music in La Paz. However, shortly after, he traveled to the Federal Republic of Germany, where he continued his studies at the Pfälzische Musikakademie (Palatinate Music Academy) in the city of Speyer in the Rhineland Palatinate and then at the Higher School of Music from the city of Karlsruhe. In 1996 he returned to Bolivia.
    Halas works include compositions for piano, vocal, solo instruments, chamber music, choral music, concert music, symphonic and incidental. His compositional work can be recognized according to the place and time in which it was generated. Halas juvenile work (1980 – 1986) includes a large collection of works, the vast majority outside the official catalog of works and the vast majority unpublished. Works from this time of production include: the cantata El Canto de los Sepulcros (The Song for the Tombs) (1984) for soloists, mixed choir and chamber ensemble composed for the Bolivian Choral Society; the Allegro Brusco Op.3 (1985); the Misa Interdicta (the Prohibited Mass) Op.6 (1987) and the melodrama for baritone and piano on the homonymous narrative by F. Kafka Report for an Academy Op.4 (1986). His European period (1987 – 1994) begins with the composition Concertino for transverse flute and string orchestra Op.8 (1988);  Réquiem para la Selva Amazónica (Requiem for the Amazon Jungle) Op.10 (1990); wind quintet Op.12 (1992); and Toccata for solo cello Op.14 (1993). Halas Bolivian period (1995 to the present) include works that seek inspiration from Bolivian traditions and popular music. Representative works include Cantos Líticos (Lithic Songs) Op.16 for voice and piano;  Álbum para un Ratón Criollo (Album for a Creole Mouse) Op.20 (1998), El Cóndor y la Tormenta (the Condor and the Storm) Op.24 (2001), Alasita - I Book Op. 28 (2004), Jacha Flowers Homenaje Blues (Jacha Flowers Homenaje Blues) Op.29 (2004), El Entierro del Pepino  (The Cucumber Burial) Op.32 (2010), Waca Concertino Op.26 (2006 - 2018) and the burlesque for solo saxophone Chuta Cholero Op.41 (2020).In addition to his solo work, Halas  has also worked to create original sound tracks for films. He has worked for Oscar García on the soundtracks for movies by Jorge Sanjinés and Marcos Loayza. In 2005, he made the original music for the Fernando Vargas film “Di buen día a Papá” (Say good day to Dad).    
	As a music teacher, he has thrived as an academic authority in various positions. Between 2002 and 2003 he was a professor of music at the Bolivian Catholic University. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the National Conservatory of Music (2002-2007), head of the Academic Unit of the National Conservatory of Music (2008-2010), executive director of the National Conservatory of Music in La Paz. (2010-2013) and rector of the new Plurinational Conservatory of Music (2013-2015).
    Halas has been distinguished with several prizes and recognitions as an artist and composer. In  2009 he received a recognition for his 20 years of career in the dissemination of music, artistic and cultural events, granted by the Honorable Congress of the Republic of Bolivia. He also received recognition from the Parliamentary Brigade of the City of La Paz, and the Medal of Cultural Merit, for Musical composition by the Bolivian Association "Pro Arte" in 2014.

title: Jorge Andres Ibáñez
description: Ibáñez's music is characterized by its lyricism, clarity of form, refinement, spontaneity, and use of resonance and instrumentation. Born in La Paz, Bolivia, Ibáñez began his musical studies under the guidance of his parents, both distinguished Bolivian musicians. He graduated from the National Conservatory of Music in La Paz in 1983 and taught piano at the conservatory for three years after graduating. Ibáñez holds a Graduate Diploma in Piano from the Longy School of Music, a Bachelor of Music in Composition from the New England Conservatory of Music, and a Master of Music in Composition from Carnegie Mellon University. His primary teachers in composition have been Lukas Foss, Theodore Antoniou, Leonardo Balada, John McDonald, Malcolm Peyton, and Robert Kyr. He has also received piano lessons from Sally Pinkas, Gustavo Navarre, and Alicia de Justiniano.                                                                                   Ibáñez is a winner of several composition awards. He won second prize at the Simon Bolivar Composition Contest in 1983, the second prize Winner at the Humberto Viscarra Monje Piano Competition in 1985, an Honorable Mention at the Carnegie Mellon University Composition Contest in 1995, and won the third prize in the Teresa Rivera de Stahlie National Composition Contest in 1998. He frequently performs in concerts in South America and the United States as a member of Duo Ibáñez with his brother Luis Antonio Ibáñez, a violin and piano duo, and with Ritmos 3 (Rhythm 3), a violin, piano, and percussion trio. He also serves as the instrumentalist, composer, and member of the choral group Triad: Boston's Choral Collective. He recorded the album “In Memoriam” in 2014, a compilation that includes violin and piano compositions from Bolivian composers Antonio Ibáñez Rodriguez and Gustavo Navarre Viscarra and his works with Duo Ibáñez. In addition to his work as a composer, director, and musician, Ibáñez has taught music at the New World School for the Arts and Broward College in Miami, Florida. He currently teaches at Winchester Community Music School and Roxbury Community College. Ibáñez lives in Boston with his wife, Deborah, daughter Katarina, and son Mateo.

title: Luis Moya Salguero
description: Moya is a composer of contemporary classical music. He has composed numerous works for piano, choir, symphony orchestra, chamber music, soloists and orchestra. He has published three works for trio (piano, violin and cello) in the series Compositores Bolivianos (Bolivian Composers), No. XXV, Música para Trío (Music for Trio) (2004). In 2009 Moya authored the book Invenciones sobre la sonoridad Andina (Inventions on Andean Sonority) about the musical aesthetic thinking of Alberto Villapando. From February 2011 to February 2014, he was the president of the Bolivian Association of Authors, Researchers, Composers, Artists and Musicians (ABAICAM), a non-profit association whose main objective is the promotion of creation, organization of training events, registration , development, dissemination and research of contemporary Bolivian music. Every year ABAICAM organizes the Contemporary Music Conferences that take place in the month of September. In 2020, he published the book Sin privilegios, Horizonte de la formación musical superior en Cochabamba (Without privileges, Horizons of higher musical training in Cochamaba). In 2013, Moya founded the of the bachelor's program in music at the Major University of San Simón de Cochabamba in 2013. He headed the music department from 2016 to 2020. He is still an instructor at the  Major University of San Simón, where he teaches harmony and instrumentation and orchestration.

title: Ronaldo Christian Peña Guillén
description:
Peña Guillen began his musical studies at the age of ten and at the age of sixteen he began his studies at the National Conservatory of Music in La Paz in 1991. In 1999, he graduated from the conservatory with “Distinction” as a classical guitarist. In 2013, Peña Guillen began to study music from the University of Loyola Bolivia in La Paz. He also holds a bachelor’s degree in Pedagogy from the Autonomous University of Beni. In addition to his academic studies, Peña Guillen has also studied guitar under Miguel Cerruto and Gentaro Takada and participated in master classes with renowned guitarists Piraí Vaca, Javier Calderón, Ben Kearsley, Christopher Jaggins, and Gerardo Pérez. He attended seminars on Chopin’s and Bach’s work with Spanish pianist Inocencio Negrín. While at the conservatory he studied composition with Gastón Arce, and attended seminars with composers Cergio Prudencio, Edgar Alandia, José Luis Prudencio, and Graciela Paraskevaidis.
While studying at the conservatory, Peña Guillen began to teach classical guitar, solfeggio and music theory, harmony, counterpoint, and musical forms since 1996. He enjoys helping to train many generations of musicians, introducing new methodologies, and incorporating the use of innovative resources in musical pedagogy. He is currently a teacher at the National Conservatory where he teaches harmony, counterpoint, musical forms, and analysis. He has also taught at the Universidad Mayor de San Andrés. Peña Guillen is also a prolific orator, he periodically gives lectures at seminars and conferences on Christian worldview from 2008 to date and other courses on different musical themes.
	From Peña Guillen’s compositions for guitar and orchestra two stand out from his body of works. The first is the piece Concert No. 1 (the first Bolivian work of its kind), which premiered in 2007 by the National Symphony Orchestra with Héctor Osaky on guitar. The second is the Fire Concert (Concert No. 2, 2014), which premiered in 2016 by guitarist Marcos Puña. His body of work also include several piano pieces,  including two compositions that were awarded with a first and second prize for composition in two categories in the second NationalNational Competition of piano works for children “María Teresa Rivera-Sthalie” with his works Juegos and Acuarelas, in 2012. He has also composed many works for solo guitar, chamber music, compositions for symphonic band, wind instruments and synthesizers. In 2015 she composed the work for solo guitar Auqui-Auqui for the renowned Japanese classical guitarist

title: Simeón Tadeo Roncal Gallardo
description:
Born in Sucre Roncal Gallardo was the son of Mrs. Rosa Gallardo and Juan Roncal. His father was the maestro of the Chapel of the Metropolitan Cathedral of La Plata, organist, and cantor of the Mother Church of Potosí. He began to study piano at the age of seven with his father. After surpassing his father’s knowledge, he began to receive lessons from the Spanish Emilio Gott. At nine, he became the organist of the Metropolitan Cathedral of Sucre. Roncal Gallardo studied and taught himself harmony, structure, and musical composition. At 13, he was appointed the second organist of the metropolitan cathedral. He was known as a piano virtuoso and very affectionately called the left-hander for his ability to play the bass notes on the piano. 
        As a composer, Roncal Gallardo produced 40 cuecas for concert, kaluyos, dance, marches, and hymns. He wrote and dedicated the cueca Huérfana Virginia (Orphan Virginia) for his wife Mrs. Virginia Cortés after the death of her mother. He was one of the founders of the Philharmonic of the city of Sucre and one of the principal components of Gesta Barbara in Potosi. He worked as a piano teacher in schools in Potosí, where he lived for ten years (1917-1927) and joined Gesta Bárbara. In 1927 he moved to La Paz, where he lived until January 13, 1953, the date of his death.

title: Ramiro Soriano Acre
description: Soriano Acre studied at the National Conservatory of Music in La Paz, Bolivia. He studied under the Armenian Soviet composer Rubén Vartañán, who served as the Artistic Director and Principal Conductor with National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia in the 1970s. He studied under Boris Jaykin and Gennady Rozhdestvensky at the "Tchaikovsky" Conservatory in Moscow, where he obtained the title of master of arts, specializing in symphony orchestra and opera conducting and completed the "Aspirantura", a Post Graduate course. From 1982 to 1991 he was principal conductor of the National Symphony Orchestra of Bolivia with which, to this day, he appears as guest conductor. Since 1982 he has been director of Coral Nova. In 1987 he was invited with a scholarship from the French government, and stayed four months in Paris observing the work of the Paris Orchestra, the French National Orchestra and the New French Radio and TV Philharmonic Orchestra. As a conductor, he has conducted in the United States, Russia, Portugal, Argentina, Peru, Colombia and Ecuador. He founded the National Symphony Orchestra of Honduras in 1990, and was its Principal Conductor until 1994. As a composer, he has composed for orchestra, choir, a chamber, vocal and solo instruments; he has also done choral arrangements and composed music for film.

title: Nicolás Suarez Eyzaguirre
description:
Nicolas Suarez Eyzaguirre is a composer, pianist, arranger, consultant and music producer. He received a bachelor of music from the Universidad Católica Boliviana San Pablo (1978), a master’s (1986), and a Ph.D. in music (1997) from the Catholic University of America in Washington D.C.. Suarez Eyzaguirre was the composer in residence of the National Symphony Orchestra in La Paz from 2002 to 2005 and the Director of the Plurinational Conservatory of Music from 2000 to 2005. He won the first prize in the Composition Contest "Adrián Patiño" of the Municipal Mayor's Office of La Paz in 2010, 2014, and 2018. He conducted the National Symphony Orchestra at the "Wara Sinfónico" event in 2011 and more recently at the "Cantos de Amor" concert in November 2021.
         In November 2011, Suarez Eyzaguirre presented his opera  El Compadre, a work reprised in 2017. He has won the Plurinational Prize for musical composition "Eduardo Abaroa" twice in 2016 and 2017. Among his recordings that stand out are Canciones para niños (Songs for Children) Vol.1 (2009) and Vol.2 (2020), Música para orquesta, coro, canciones y ensambles (Music for orchestra, choir, songs, and ensembles) (2010) and Blues en las Rockas (Blues in the Rockas) (2013). In addition, Suarez Eyzaguirre also worked on the production and publication of his opera El Compadre (2019) in DVD format and the animated children’s title entitled “Planting dreams in the forest” (2020) available in DVD format. His composition work also extends into various musical genres. He has recorded with New Albion Records(1990), Pro Audio(2009 and 2011), Elektra (2013, 2019, 2020), León Estudios (2019), Discolandia (1994), OOdiscs, CT (1998), Kantus (2002).

title: Teofilo Vargas Candia
description:
Teófilo Vargas Candia was born in Quillacollo on November 3, 1866 and died in Cochabamba on February 3, 1961. Vargas Candia was a Bolivian violinist, composer, and director. In 1893 he became the maestro of the Cochabamba cathedral choir. He was a founder of the music school (1884) and the conservatory (1907) in Cochabamba. Vargas Candia was the director of the conservatory from 1907-1956 and in 1957 it was renamed the “Teófilo Vargas Candia Conservatory” in honor of his service.
    As a student of popular Bolivian forms, the six volumes of  Aires Nacionales de Bolivia (National Airs of Bolivia),  Himno a Cochabamba (the Hymn of Cochabamba) and Quillacollo, the melodramas Aroma and Coronilla and his Christmas Oratory stand out. At the age of 16 he composes his first composition for piano and violin that would later be part of the first volume of his works Aires Nacionales de Bolivia. Its second volume was printed in 1940 with 22 cuecas and dances for voice and piano. The following year the third volume and part of his work Aires Nacionales de Bolivia was printed in Bolivia and Santiago, Chile, this volume includes 22 pieces for voice, overtures, preludes, dances, symphonic poems, songs, and patriotic marches. His fourth volume, was edited and printed in Argentina and contains Christmas carols, songs, hymns, and funeral marches.

title: Jose Maria Velasco Maidana
description:
Velasco Maidana was born in Sucre in 1901. He composed several musical works for his ballet group and symphonic works. His work, Suite India, is an autochthonous reference of his work. In 1940 he founded the Symphony Concert Orchestra, the precursor to the Orquesta Sinfónica Nacional de Bolivia. He also organized the Amerindian ballet, with which he toured several countries in America and Europe. 
	In addition to his musical career, Velasco Maidana is also known as the fundamental filmmaker of the silent stage of Bolivian cinema. His first major film was La Profecía del Lago (The Lake Prophecy) (1925), the story of the daughter of a landowner falling in love with an Aymara man, that was never released due to government censorship. His second film of the time, Wara Wara (1930), a story of the Spanish conquest in the lake area, was positively received.  Wara Wara was a grand feature film during this time, as it featured recreated set designs and models of the original time period and a great cast. Velasco Maidana spent the last years of his life in the United States, where he died in 1989 in Texas at age 88.

title: Humberto Viscarra Monje
description:
Bolivian composer, born in Sorata in 1898 and died in La Paz in 1971. He studied at the National Conservatory of Music in La Paz shortly after it opened, while it was under the direction of Peruvian David Molina. Later he expanded his studies in Europe, specifically in Italy and France, where he became a piano virtuoso and a composer of international fame and level. He was also a notable writer, poet, and an illustrious educator. He directed the National Conservatory of La Paz and was director and founder, with Armando Palmero, of the famous 
Man Césped Music Academy in Cochabamba.
        His musical compositions are characterized by a combination of popular elements of his time and Bolivian native music. In his piano works he introduced melodies with great expressive elegance and harmonic transparency. Some of his noteworthy composition include: Pequeña Danza (Small Dance), Motivo Aymara (Aymara Reason) , Capricho Andino (Andean Caprice), Allegretto Scherzando, and, Rondino, his most popular piano piece.

title: Gustavo Navarre
description:
A pioneer among the musicians of his generation, Navarre is one of the most influential Bolivian composers of his time. Born in La Paz in 1931, he began his formal musical education at an early age, and in 1947 he became a student of Egon-Carl Schif. The following year he entered the National Conservatory of Music of La Paz, to continue his piano studies under the tutelage of Alicia Eguino de Justiniano and Mario Estensoro. While at the conservatory he studied music theory with Teófilo Molina, and harmony and counterpoint with Erich Eisner. Nine years after entering the conservatory, he was appointed professor in 1957 and began to teach harmony, counterpoint and composition as professor at the conservatory. In 1968, he participated in a competition in Geneva, Switzerland, where he was awarded a scholarship to study music at the Ecole Normale de Musique in Paris, France. During this period, he studied orchestration, composition, and musical analysis with world-renowned composers such as Henri Dutilleux (1916-2013) and Marcel Mihalovici (1898-1985). After returning to Bolivia, Navarre became the 
Director of the National Conservatory of Music in 1970. Navarre has received many recognitions including several national awards including, the Ministry of Education Award, and the prestigious Luz Mila Patiño Award. Navarre died in La Paz in 2006.
    Gustavo Navarre was a prolific composer, unfortunately most of his work was lost in a fire in the 1990’s. Items lost include original, plain copies, manuscripts, and a catalog of his works. It is only through his colleagues, fellow musicians, family, and friends accounts of his prolific production are known. Fellow composer, Atiliano Auza describes his composition style as neo-romantic, but with a local influence. Musicologists Suzanne Spicer Tiemstra and Gerard Béhague describe his style as a combination of neo-romanticism with Bolivian elements and nationalism.The musicologist Leslie Bethell affirms that Navarre had "created a neo-romantic language sometimes combined with features of Bolivian folk music.” Navarre work included 
written vocal works, sonatas, piano trios, string quartets, and piano quintets, as well as larger orchestral compositions, including at least two symphonies. 
	The news of this loss was devastating not only for the Navarre family but also for Bolivia's musical heritage. However, to the surprise of many, some of Navarre's compositions have emerged recently. Photocopies of a Sonata for violin and piano, a string quartet, a short Elegy for violin and piano, and a symphony in two movements have been found in private collections and the library of the National Symphony Orchestra in La Paz. In June 2012, during a concert trip to Bolivia, researcher Javier Pinell and co-researcher Sergio Ruiz became aware of these results and the idea of ​​compiling these manuscripts, their study, public presentation, and recording

title: Canela Palacios
description: Palacios studied under composers Alberto Villalpando, Cergio Prudencio, Coriún Aharonián, Graciela Paraskevaídis and Cornelius Schwehr. In 2011 she founded, together with several colleagues, the Casa Taller collective, a meeting and creation space in La Paz. In 2015, together with the Casa Taller team, Palacios created the “School of Composition” of which she was director. She is the creator and person in charge of the Bolivian Contemporary Music project. She was co-founder, composer and performer of songs of the Abrelata Duo. Palacios has composed for contemporary music ensembles from Bolivia and other countries. Her music has been performed at contemporary music festivals in Bolivia, Colombia and Germany. She has also collaborated with artists from various disciplines in dance, theater, film and performance projects. In 2020 she published the popular music album Sur (South).
